bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, January 8, 1929

div1.p: Carter informs Frost that she has duplicated bibliographic references for the manuscript, but that the flu has slowed her efforts.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, January 8, 1929
div1.opener:
Book
Bibliography
Frost (W. H.)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N.W.
Washington, D. C.
January 8, 1929.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
Just to tell you that I can return all of the library [unclear]card II I
took from your bibliographic files for Father's History of Yellow
Fever as soon as either Miss Brown or I are well enough to go to a
post office to register them. Miss Brown went on sick leave this morn-
ing--“flu” I fear. Since my return from Baltimore we have made du-
plicates of all the library cards which I brought back with me, which du-
plicates I shall keep until I have retyped the remaining bibliographic
cards you wished made clearer. The above work did not take long (Miss
Brown did most of it at night) and I felt sure that you would much
rather have the bibliographicacutal library cards than a Memorandum of which ones I
had taken from your files.

Haven't been able to do as much typewriting on the bibliographic
cards as I hoped (thanks to the “flu”), but I hopetrust that I can push it
from now on. Wish much I could have postponed this attack until the
cards were done. Wish, also, one could estimate clinically, as one can
do in structual engineering, just how much strain can be endured without
a complete smash. I am not afraid of pain--though very weary of it!--
but I do dread disability until everything I can do about the book is done.
After that being “scrapped” would make little difference. Sorry!--
didn't mean to become autogbiographic. That's the worst of being turned
loose with a typewriter at the end of a hard day.
I'm so glad your family is “out of the woods.”
